generated_questions.content: Background (implicit for all questions)

“One of the two people sitting on the right of the salesperson is also a salesperson” implies there is a salesperson at the left end (so there are two people to that salesperson’s right), and since the rightmost is accountant, the middle must be a salesperson.
The 24‑year‑old sits in the leftmost seat.

options: 一项研究给部分学生补充特定维生素，补充组考试成绩显著高于未补充组，研究者因此认为该维生素能提升记忆力并且效果可维持数月。

微电击一定不会对数学能力产生任何影响。

对照组的人数一定少于25人。

generated_questions.content: 不当概括陷阱：文中研究者认为“微电击可以提高大脑的计算力”。下列哪项是从文中断言推导出的不合理过度推广？

Explanation/Resolution — The passage states that the cave dates to the Neolithic Age yet was not discovered until the 1950s. Which of the following best explains why both statements can be true without contradiction?

Direct inference — Which of the following can be most directly inferred from the passage?
options: Symptoms of vitamin deficiency in pregnant women are generally caused by inadequate diets.
Fetal growth commonly increases maternal vitamin requirements, which explains many deficiency symptoms in pregnant women.
All pregnant women will show vitamin deficiency symptoms at some point.
Pregnant women who increase vitamin intake never show deficiency symptoms.

generated_questions.content: Missing premise — The author's claim that deficiency symptoms are usually not due to lack of vitamins in the diet but to fetal growth depends on which unstated assumption?
options: Pregnant women's diets typically provide sufficient vitamins for nonpregnant adult needs (so diet alone does not explain the symptoms).
Vitamins cannot be absorbed at all during pregnancy.
Every pregnant woman takes prenatal vitamin supplements.
Fetal growth always reduces a mother's appetite.

generated_questions.content: Strengthen — Which of the following, if true, would most strengthen the author's explanation?
options: Most pregnant women consume the recommended amounts of vitamins yet still exhibit deficiency symptoms.
Many pregnant women avoid vitamin-rich foods during pregnancy.
A new medication increases vitamin absorption in middle-aged nonpregnant adults.
The price of vitamin-rich foods has risen recently.

generated_questions.content: Weaken — Which of the following, if true, would most seriously weaken the author's claim that fetal growth (higher demand) is the usual cause of these deficiency symptoms?
options: Surveys show a large proportion of pregnant women have diets far below recommended vitamin intakes.
Studies show that fetal uptake of vitamins from the mother is negligible.
Most pregnant women regularly take prenatal vitamins.
Vitamin deficiency symptoms are impossible to measure reliably.

generated_questions.content: Conditional reasoning — If pregnant women increased their dietary vitamin intake so that total maternal intake exactly matched the combined needs of mother plus fetus, which of the following would most likely be true?
options: The frequency of vitamin-deficiency symptoms among pregnant women would decrease.
The frequency of deficiency symptoms would remain unchanged.
Dietary intake would become irrelevant to maternal vitamin status.
Fetal growth would necessarily increase further.

generated_questions.content: Explanation/Resolution — Which statement best explains the apparent fact that many pregnant women show vitamin-deficiency symptoms even though the cause is not lack of vitamins in the diet?
options: The fetus's growth creates increased maternal vitamin demand or transfer to the fetus, producing maternal deficiency symptoms despite adequate maternal diets.
Pregnant women eat less food overall, so their diet is the real cause.
Vitamin-deficiency symptoms during pregnancy are psychosomatic.
Prenatal vitamins directly cause symptoms identical to deficiency.

generated_questions.content: Parallel reasoning — Which of the following arguments is most similar in logical structure to the passage's argument?
options: Many endurance athletes experience fatigue, not because they lack calories in their diets, but because their increased training raises their energy requirements.
Many smokers develop lung disease, not because of smoking, but because of general air pollution.
Many students fail exams because they study less, not because the exams are unusually hard.
Several cities suffer blackouts due to lack of power plants, not because electricity use rose.

generated_questions.content: Scope/trap — Which of the following statements is NOT justified (not necessarily true) based solely on the passage?
options: No pregnant woman ever has a diet low enough in vitamins to cause deficiency symptoms.
Pregnant women have higher vitamin needs than nonpregnant people.
In most cases, fetal growth, rather than dietary lack, explains pregnant women's deficiency symptoms.
Dietary insufficiency can still be a cause in some pregnant women.

generated_questions.content: Hypothetical new constraint (conditional reasoning) — Suppose a study intervenes to reduce the amount of vitamins transferred from mother to fetus without changing maternal diets, and after the intervention the rate of maternal vitamin-deficiency symptoms falls. If these findings are accurate, which conclusion follows most directly?
options: Transfer of vitamins to the fetus contributes causally to maternal vitamin-deficiency symptoms.
Maternal diet is the sole cause of deficiency symptoms.
Reducing fetal transfer causes maternal diets to become deficient.
Vitamin supplements are always ineffective during pregnancy.

generated_questions.content: Direct Inference — Which of the following can be correctly inferred from the passage?

Recognizing the territories is completely irrelevant to any political settlement.
Pardoning militia members necessarily increases violence.
The speakers of the “Republics” will accept any compromise proposed by Kyiv.

generated_questions.content: Which unstated assumption is required for the “Republics’” statement — “if the Ukrainian authorities do not recognize our territories and special status, and do not stop military operations, the conflict cannot be resolved” — to have the intended force?
options: Recognition of their territories/special status and a halt to military operations are required conditions for resolving the conflict.
Granting recognition and pardons will immediately create economic prosperity in the region.
The Ukrainian authorities already intend to recognize the territories.
International law forbids any negotiation with unrecognized entities.

generated_questions.content: Which one of the following, if true, would most weaken the Ukrainian observers’ skeptical question about whether recognition and pardoning could resolve the conflict?
options: In a comparable recent case, official recognition plus a general amnesty led formerly armed militias to disarm and reintegrate, ending hostilities.
A majority of Ukrainians oppose granting special status to the separatist territories.

International monitors lack the resources to verify compliance with any agreement.

generated_questions.content: According to the “Republics’” public position (as reported), if the Ukrainian authorities grant the special status but continue military operations in the southeast, which of the following best follows?
options: The conflict still cannot be resolved.
The conflict will necessarily be resolved because recognition has been granted.
Pardoning militia members will definitely resolve the conflict despite ongoing operations.
Nothing definite follows from this combination of actions.

generated_questions.content: Which argument has the most similar logical form to the “Republics’” claim that without (recognition AND cessation of operations) the conflict cannot be resolved?
options: Unless the company both cuts costs and increases sales, it will not return to profitability.
If the company cuts costs, it will automatically become profitable.
Without a map, hikers may become lost.
Even if the company cuts costs and increases sales, it might still fail due to external factors.

generated_questions.content: Which statement best explains why Ukrainian observers pose the questions “Do we recognize the special status… and can we resolve the conflict by pardoning the militia?”
options: They doubt that recognition and pardons would remove the fundamental causes of conflict or prevent future violence, so they question whether those measures would actually resolve the problem.
They are confident that recognizing the “Republics” would immediately restore international support for Ukraine.

They assume that the speakers of the “Republics” will accept any compromise once offered.

Direct inference — Which of the following can be validly inferred from the passage's premise?
options: If no one is deceived, then there are neither scammers nor greedy people in that society.
If no one is deceived, then either there are no scammers or there are no greedy people.
If no one is deceived, then scammers certainly still exist.
If no one is deceived, then greed must still exist but produce no cheating.

generated_questions.content: Conditional reasoning — If we add the hypothesis "Scammers still exist in that society after progress," which of the following must be true?
options: No one in that society is cheated.
Some people in that society remain greedy.
No one in that society is greedy.
Scammers will stop attempting deception.

generated_questions.content: Conditional reasoning (reverse) — If we add the hypothesis "At least one person in that society remains greedy after progress," which of the following must be true?
options: No one is deceived in that society.
There are no scammers in that society.
Someone must be cheated in that society.
Scammers and greedy people cannot coexist there.

generated_questions.content: Missing premise — Which additional assumption, if explicitly added to the passage, would make the conclusion ("if no one is deceived, then greed has been universally eliminated") logically valid?
options: It is impossible for scammers to exist in any advanced society.
Scammers necessarily continue to exist in that society despite progress.
Greedy people never change their behavior.
Cheating can occur even without scammers.

generated_questions.content: Which logical error best describes the reasoning that goes from ¬(someone is cheated) to "people must have universally eliminated greed"?
options: Affirming the consequent.
Denying a conjunct (inferring ¬G from ¬(S ∧ G) instead of recognizing ¬S ∨ ¬G).
Confusing necessity with sufficiency in the opposite direction (i.e., assuming greed → cheating).
Equivocation on the term "progress."

generated_questions.content: Strengthen — Which additional fact would most strengthen the argument that if no one is deceived then greed must have been universally eliminated?
options: There exist laws that punish cheating harshly.
Scammers are guaranteed to persist in any society (they cannot be fully eliminated).
Many people publicly renounce greed but privately remain greedy.
Some people are both scammers and immune to punishment.

generated_questions.content: Weaken — Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the passage's conclusion that the absence of deception implies universal elimination of greed?
options: There is evidence that a recent campaign eradicated greedy impulses in many people.
Scammers were completely removed from the society as part of the progress.
Greed and deception are shown to be logically identical.
Cheating is defined to include only large-scale fraud.

generated_questions.content: Explanation/Resolution — The passage's conclusion appears stronger than what the premises guarantee. Which statement best explains this apparent discrepancy?
options: The argument silently assumes that scammers cannot be eliminated, so the only way to stop cheating is to eliminate greed.
The argument incorrectly assumes that everyone who is greedy becomes a scammer.
The argument redefines "cheated" to mean something unrelated.
The argument equivocates on the meaning of "society."

generated_questions.content: Parallel reasoning — Which of the following arguments has the same logical form (and the same invalid move) as the passage?
options: If there are faulty brakes and reckless drivers, then accidents will occur. Therefore, if no accidents occur, drivers must have universally stopped being reckless.
If a product is expensive then few buy it. Therefore, if many buy it, the product must be cheap.
If it rains then the ground gets wet. If the ground is wet, then it must have rained.
If a machine is switched off then it uses no power. Therefore, if it uses no power, the machine must be switched off.

generated_questions.content: (Parallel reasoning) Which of the following arguments has the same logical form as the passage (i.e., A → B; ¬A; therefore ¬B)?
options: All mammals are animals. Whales are not mammals. Therefore whales are not animals.
If it rains, the streets get wet. The streets are wet. Therefore it rained.
Everyone who owns a car can drive. Alice owns a car. Therefore Alice can drive.

generated_questions.content: (Explanation / resolution) Suppose many people identify as both Taiwanese and Chinese despite the argument in the passage. Which of the following best explains this apparent discrepancy?

The People’s Republic of China recently changed its laws to include Taiwan.
Taiwanese people are legally stateless and therefore cannot be Chinese.
The argument’s premises are universally accepted facts about nationality everywhere.

Below is a set of multiple-choice questions that probe the logical consequences, conditionals, assumptions, and possible/impossible scenarios entailed by the short passage. Each question assumes the passage is correct and — unless the question explicitly adds a new condition — also uses the fact stated in the passage: exactly one of the three instructors' statements is true.
Which of the following statements MUST be true given the polling results as reported?

The percentages given are: 40% (unfair US foreign policy), 55% (civilizational conflict), 23% (evil nature of terrorists), and 19% (no view). Which of the following is a correct numerical inference (treat percentages as of a 100-person sample)?
Assume the poll used 100 respondents. What is the minimum possible number of respondents who selected more than one of the three listed causes?
Which of the following is the BEST single explanation for why the cause-percentages sum to more than 100% (40+55+23+19 = 137%)?
Which unstated assumption is required to conclude from the reported percentages that "some respondents attributed the attacks to more than one cause"?
If it were later revealed that the survey instructions forced each respondent to choose exactly one cause (single-choice), which of the following MUST be true?
Which additional piece of information would most STRONGLY strengthen the interpretation that respondents commonly endorsed multiple causes?
Which of the following can be validly inferred from the two statements?
If, in addition to the two given statements, it is known that every worker is a southerner, which of the following must be true?
Which additional premise would be sufficient (together with the original two statements) to validly conclude "Some northerners are workers"?
Which of the following, if true, would most seriously weaken the claim "No northerner is a worker"?
Which description of the relationships among the sets H (people in Harbin), N (northerners), and W (workers) is consistent with the two statements?
Suppose someone adds the premise "Every northerner is a worker." Which of the following must then be false (i.e., logically incompatible with the full set of premises)?
Which of the following arguments has the same logical form as the original pair of statements (i.e., "All X are Y; Some X are not Z")?

Direct inference — Which of the following must be true?
Direct inference — Who is the man that meets all three of Li Na's requirements (tall, handsome, and a doctor)?
Constraint-satisfaction — Which of the following assignment of attributes (Tall / Doctor / Handsome) to the four men is consistent with all statements?
Conditional reasoning — If Li Qiang were the handsome man (contrary to what you can deduce from the full set of statements), which of the following would necessarily be true?

Conditional reasoning — If it were discovered that Wang Wei is tall (contrary to the deduction from the original constraints), which of the following would follow directly from the given statements plus that discovery?
Missing-premise — To validly conclude that Wang Wei is the only non-tall man (and thus Wu Gang is the only doctor who can be tall), which implicit assumption is required?
Strengthen — Which additional fact, if added to the original statements, would most strongly reinforce the conclusion that Wu Gang is the man who satisfies all three of Li Na's requirements?

(Direct inference) Which of the following can be directly inferred from the passage?
options: The United States and Japan are among the countries that have blamed their domestic economic problems on China’s fixed exchange rate.
China’s fixed exchange rate is the only cause of economic problems in the United States and Japan.
All domestic manufacturing companies in the United States and Japan caused economic pressure.
China intentionally set its exchange rate to harm other countries’ economies.

generated_questions.content: (Missing premise / Necessary assumption) The claim that China’s fixed exchange rate explains some countries’ domestic economic problems relies on which unstated assumption?
options: Changes in China’s exchange rate affect the international competitiveness of other countries’ industries.
The United States and Japan have identical economic structures.
Domestic manufacturing companies always blame foreign policy for their problems.
China’s economy is larger than the economies of all complaining countries combined.

generated_questions.content: (Weaken) Which of the following, if true, would most seriously weaken the view that China’s fixed exchange rate is the cause of those countries’ domestic economic problems?
options: Several complaining countries also experienced economic problems before China adopted its current exchange‑rate policy.
After China adjusted its exchange rate policy, the complaining countries’ economic problems persisted unchanged.
Some studies show a statistical correlation between China’s exchange rate and foreign manufacturing output.
Domestic manufacturing firms in the complaining countries benefited from lower input costs unrelated to exchange rates.

generated_questions.content: (Explanation / Resolution) The passage mentions both (1) some countries blaming China’s fixed exchange rate and (2) “some domestic manufacturing companies have caused pressure.” Which statement best explains this apparent tension?
options: Domestic manufacturing companies are pressuring their governments to attribute their difficulties to China’s exchange rate in order to shift public attention from domestic causes.
The governments secretly set China’s exchange rate policy and therefore blame themselves.
The passage implies that only domestic companies caused the economic problems, so blaming China is purely rhetorical.
China’s exchange rate policy directly forces domestic companies to exert political pressure.

generated_questions.content: (Conditional reasoning) If it turned out that none of the domestic manufacturing companies in the complaining countries exported goods to or competed with Chinese producers, which of the following must be true (given only the passage)?
options: The countries’ blame of China’s fixed exchange rate would be definitely incorrect.
Domestic manufacturing companies could not have been a source of pressure on their governments.
The passage alone would not provide sufficient basis to conclude that China’s exchange rate caused the countries’ economic problems.
The United States and Japan would stop blaming China immediately.

generated_questions.content: (Parallel reasoning) Which of the following arguments is most parallel in logical structure to the passage’s account (i.e., some actors blame factor X for domestic problems; some domestic actors have caused pressure)?
options: Several cities claim their rising crime rate is due to streaming services; some neighborhood associations have staged protests demanding action.
A researcher proved that caffeine improves memory; therefore all students should drink coffee.
The mayor said unemployment rose because of global warming; scientists demonstrated the opposite.
Every company increased prices because raw materials became scarce; consumers accepted the increases peacefully.

generated_questions.content: (Constraint satisfaction / Consistency) Which of the following sets of statements is fully consistent with the passage?
options: Some countries (including the US and Japan) blame China’s fixed exchange rate; some domestic manufacturers have increased political pressure; all countries blame China.
Some countries (especially the US and Japan) blame China’s fixed exchange rate; some domestic manufacturers have caused pressure; there may be other causes of domestic economic problems.
No country blames China; domestic manufacturers are the sole cause of economic problems in all complaining countries.
China’s fixed exchange rate is admitted by the passage to be the sole and proven cause of manufacturing decline worldwide.

generated_questions.content: (Scope / Reverse‑logic trap) Which statement directly contradicts the passage?
options: Only a handful of countries have blamed China’s fixed exchange rate for economic difficulties.
The passage says the United States and Japan are especially likely to blame China’s exchange‑rate policy.
All countries in the world blame China’s fixed exchange rate for their domestic economic problems.
Some domestic manufacturing companies have generated pressure related to these issues.

generated_questions.content: Which of the following is a direct inference from the statement "Do not do what you don't want to do to others"?
options: You should not perform on others any action you would not want performed on yourself.
You must actively do for others everything you would like them to do for you.
People always act in ways that maximize their own pleasure.

generated_questions.content: Someone argues from the maxim that "Therefore lying to others is wrong." Which of the following is the missing premise that makes this argument valid?

People do not want others to lie to them.

Lying is illegal in many societies.

generated_questions.content: If a person applies the rule "Do not do what you don't want to do to others" consistently to every possible action, which of the following must be true?

If they would not want to be helped, then they must help others.

generated_questions.content: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the claim that the maxim is a universally reliable moral guide across all societies?

Most people find the maxim easy to remember and teach to children.
Some ethical systems emphasize positive duties (obligations to help) rather than only prohibitions.

generated_questions.content: Which of the following arguments is most parallel in logical form to "Do not do what you don't want to do to others"?

If you dislike loud music, then everyone else must also dislike loud music.
If you dislike loud music, then authorities should ban it everywhere.
Playing loud music proves you are inconsiderate.

generated_questions.content: The rule is negatively phrased (prohibits doing to others what you wouldn't want done to you). options: The maxim is a rule about refraining from harmful acts (negative duty); it does not by itself establish positive duties (obligations to rescue), which require additional moral principles.
The maxim actually requires you to rescue anyone if you would prefer to be rescued.
The maxim forbids only intentional acts, not omissions or failures to help.
The maxim applies only where the law requires action.

generated_questions.content: Four actions are under consideration: Lying, Helping, Stealing, Praising. A person would not want lying or stealing done to them; they would welcome helping and praising. According to the maxim, which of the following must the person refrain from doing to others?
options: Refrain from lying and from stealing; praising and helping are not required nor prohibited by the maxim.
Refrain from helping and praising; lying and stealing are permitted.
Refrain from lying and praising only.
Refrain from all four actions toward others.

The writer asserts that Confucius definitely did not say it.

generated_questions.content: To validly move from "I would not want X done to me" to "Therefore I should not do X to others," which general assumption must be accepted?
options: Others necessarily have identical preferences to mine.
